channel.title: Home on R-Ladies Lausanne
channel.description: Recent content in Home on R-Ladies Lausanne

item.title: News August 2018
item.description: Since our last newsletter in May a few things have happened: In June we had our 4th meetup before the summer break, R-Ladies Global launched a new Community Slack, and we caught up with two of our speakers in an interview. We are currently planning our meetups in Autumn, with the first meetup being in October ‚û°Ô∏è check our meetup page for updates. We are also looking for speakers and venues, please contact us via lausanne@rladies.

item.title: Interview with Elizaveta Semenova
item.description: I think there is a lot of power in the Bayesian approach. The problem is the high entrance threshold due to the computational issues that it poses. So I am always very happy to talk about the benefits of Bayesian statistics and show how simple a model can look like. In past April, Elizaveta Semenova gave an introduction to Bayesian inference in R, using Stan at our third meetup.

item.title: Interview with Leonore Wigger
item.description:
The learning process is always two fold. On the one side it’s really just learning about statistical concepts and methods, but then on the other hand it’s also about to program the analysis in R. At our very first meetup, Leonore Wigger gave a short presentation on how to arrange multiple ggplot plots onto multipage PDFs.
R-Ladies Lausanne: What is the work that you do? Leonore Wigger: I work 50% at the Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics and the other 50% at the University of Lausanne, at the Lausanne Genomic Technologies Facility, which is a service provider for RNA and DNA analysis.

item.title: Interview with Elisabeth Dahlqwist
item.description:
The reason I presented at R-Ladies, is, that when I had done my first shiny app, I felt it was really amazing and I really wanted to share my experience of doing that, because it was quite easy. Elisabeth Dahlqwist gave an introduction to Shiny at our second R-Ladies Lausanne meetup.
Sina Rüeger: What is the work that you do? Elisabeth Dahlqwist: I’m a PhD student in Biostatistics at Karoliska Institute in Stockholm.

item.title: News May 2018
item.description: Meetup #4 on June 7 @ ImpactHub We will have our fourth meetup on June 7, 2018, 7 pm at ImpactHub (door opens at 6:30 pm). During one hour we will have several speakers talking about different topics, each presentation will be 10-20 min long (aka ThundeR talks!). We also encourage you to bring along your R problems 30 min before the meetup starts - we üíúsolving R riddles!

item.title: About R-Ladies & R-Ladies Lausanne
item.description: R-Ladies is a world-wide organization to promote gender diversity in the R community. R-Ladies Global The mission of R-Ladies is to achieve proportionate representation of genders currently underrepresented in the R community by encouraging, inspiring, and empowering them. R-Ladies Global provides support to local (and remote) chapters that exist around the world. Chapters Chapters are somewhat similar to R-user groups. There are plenty of chapters around the world, listed here.

item.title: Community
item.description: Come to our meetups Participate in our meetups, talk to other R users over a drink and don’t hesitate to bring R problems along! Be a speaker As we always need R speakers for meetups, please get in touch with us! The only requirement is some passion for R. Watch out for Lightening or ThundeR talks! A great opportunity for everyone to present. Here is what you will gain from it:

item.title: Events
item.description: We have a meetup roughly every second month. The content of our meetups varies: A mix of short talks on a range of topics. This is an excellent opportunity for everyone to present what they are passionate about. For example: Favourite R packages, Applications for which you use R, The best way to learn R. How-tos/Tutorials of R-packages and applications. Are you an experienced in an R-related-topic that you would like to share and others to learn?
